text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: When it comes to trials, if it's something like, oh, give this new pill to get we give that to you. We don't bill the insurance. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: from the study standpoint. Patient: Alright, Okay. Family Member: Which is the lesser of the two evils as far as taking it long term? I’m not familiar with Cymbalta. Doctor: Well, I think Cymbalta is probably you know much more proven you know long term. The steroids can have other issues of you know blocking the immune systems likely increased risk of infections and things like that over the long term, but you know it’s – I kind of think it’s unlikely that it will help arthritic pain. If it is neuropathic nerve pain and stuff, you know Cymbalta can be effective. Patient: Yeah I think that’s what he said also yeah. Doctor: I don’t think that is the reason for your pain, but that’s my impression. Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing…

text: Patient: And I noticed you know like the first day that Doctor: Right. Family Member: Could that trigger? Doctor: Of course. Hey my other guy, you know what he did? He wasn’t going up and down the stairs. He was just working under the tree putting his little village together. Up and down, up and down; he’s got the same symptom as you. So I think – Patient: So this isn’t something that if I give it total rest for - Doctor: Oh I’m sure that it will get better if you give it total rest. But it doesn’t change this discussion that I see new areas of cancer in your bone. Whether that’s causing pain is slightly different because I’m assuming it may. But it could be worsened because you were just moving. Family Member: Hum. So they’ll radiate? Doctor: Uhn-uhn. This stuff that’s liquid goes everywhere in the bone. Family Member: Ohh! Doctor: So it isn’t like he stands there and they only shoot it up like a bone injection. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Uhn-uhn. You get an intravenous you know little catheter. Patient: And that’s going to be in me for six months.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
